profileText: A Senator from Ohio; born in Jamaica Plain, Mass., June 22, 1888; attended the public schools; graduated from Bowdoin College, Brunswick, Maine, in 1909, and from the law department of Harvard University in 1912; admitted to the bar in 1912 and commenced practice in Cleveland, Ohio; assistant attorney for a power company in Salt Lake City, Utah 1914-1916 and attorney for a power company in Boise, Idaho 1916-1917; during the First World War served in the army as lieutenant, and later as captain, in 1917 and 1918; resumed the practice of law in Cleveland, Ohio, in 1919; instructor in Western Reserve University, Cleveland, Ohio 1923-1925; member of the board of education of East Cleveland in 1928 and 1929; member, State house of representatives 1929; director of law of Cleveland 1929-1932; mayor of Cleveland 1935-1940; elected as a Republican to the United States Senate in 1940 and served from January 3, 1941, until his resignation on September 30, 1945; associate justice of the Supreme Court of the United States from 1945 until his retirement October 13, 1958; was a resident of Cleveland, Ohio; died in Georgetown University Hospital, Washington, D.C., October 28, 1964; cremated at Highland Park Cemetery, Cleveland, Ohio.

researchRecord.name: 1896-1964. 120,000 items. Correspondence, diaries, memoranda, notes, legal material, speeches, writings, newspaper clippings, printed material, and other papers, chiefly 1936-1964, covering Burton's work as mayor of Cleveland, U.S. senator and associate justice of U.S. Supreme Court. Includes a diary available on 5 microfilm reels. Finding aid.
Correspondence in Hugo L. Black papers, 1883-1976.
Correspondence in the Frank Murphy papers, 1908-1949; and Universities Committee on Post-War International Problems records, 1943-1944.
Miscellaneous items in various collections and photographs.
Correspondence in the Walter Wyatt papers, 1916-1963.
Correspondence in the Max Lerner papers, 1927-1980.
Correspondence in Frederick Moore Vinson papers, 1907-1953. Finding aid.

1927-1965. 2 feet. Chiefly copies of the Burton papers at the Library of Congress including correspondence (1933-1964); printed invitations; documents concerning 47 judicial opinions (1945-1960), including memoranda, correspondence, drafts, and printed opinions: and speeches and miscellaneous notes.
2 folders. Concern his 1940 campaign. Also campaign material in Murray Seasongood papers, 1848-1978; and a portrait. Finding aid.
In Felix Frankfurter papers, 1900-1965, available on microfilm, access restricted; Zechariah Chafee papers, 1898-1957 (bulk 1916-1956); and Joseph Berry Keenan papers, 1942-1947.
1942-1954. 69 items. Correspondence, reports, clippings, and photographs.

1911-1965. 34 containers and 14 volumes. Chiefly office, political, and personal files including correspondence, WPA reports, city utilities reports, and files of the Bituminous Coal Commission. Finding aid.

1933-1941. 10 linear feet. Correspondence, reports, speeches, proclamations, newspaper clippings, and photographs relating to Burton's career as mayor (1935-1940) and to Edward Blythin as mayor (1941) completing Burton's term after he was elected to the U.S. Senate.
Correspondence in George Washington Bicentennial Committee, Cleveland records, 1932; and campaign records in Paul W. Walter papers, 1932-1954. Finding aid.
